repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body: PyPy3.9 passes these tests, once the `sys.getrefcount` part is skipped. I am working on getting `test_asyncgen` to pass so grpcio work with PyPY, see [pypy issue 3280](https://foss.heptapod.net/pypy/pypy/-/issues/3280) and [pypy issue 3935](https://foss.heptapod.net/pypy/pypy/-/issues/3935)

comment_data.body: It seems these are only needed in the `test_async_gen_asyncio_gc_aclose_09` test I skipped. I skipped it since the cython version adds a finalizer to `tp_dealloc` which revives the object, which PyPy refuses to do and `exit()`'s instead. In the pure python version somehow that does not happen and the test fails, but does not crash. Adding a `gc.collect()` after the `del gen` to the pure python version makes the test pass.
I'm not completely sure, but I wonder if `CYTHON_USE_TYPE_SLOTS` would be the more appropriate check here (and later)

I am not sure, I thought `CYTHON_USE_TYPE_SLOTS` is for the documented dunder slots like `tp_str` -> `__str__` as generated by the [`typeslots.py`](https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/0449ffe3a4ddf03367a5ee3d943c89f442b7b407/Objects/typeslots.py#L2) code generator.
No, these are needed in more tests. Modified the github action to use the PyPy3.9 nightly that contains these functions.

`CYTHON_USE_TYPE_SLOTS` is for code that directly uses the `tp_*` slot functions of types, not for attributes on the thread state. There's `CYTHON_FAST_THREAD_STATE`, but I don't think that applies here, either. That guard controls the way we get at the thread state, more that what we do with it (although that might still depend on how fast we can get our hands on it when we need it).

If this it PyPy specific code, why not use `CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_PYPY`?

These were removed from CPython a year ago: https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/32017
That probably means they are not future proof.

Sorry for sounding a bit pedantic here, but I'd reverse these two to have the more generic option first.
```suggestion
#if CYTHON_USE_TYPE_SLOTS || CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_PYPY
```

The code-path is for non-CPython compilation. Is there a better way to work around the [opaque PyThreadState](https://docs.python.org/3/c-api/init.html?highlight=pythreadstate#c.PyThreadState) fields?

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -167,7 +167,7 @@
   #undef CYTHON_USE_MODULE_STATE
   #define CYTHON_USE_MODULE_STATE 0
   #undef CYTHON_USE_TP_FINALIZE
-  #define CYTHON_USE_TP_FINALIZE 0
+  #define CYTHON_USE_TP_FINALIZE PY_VERSION_HEX >= 0x030400a1

comment_data.body:
> The code-path is for non-CPython compilation.

Right, but the fact that CPython had them and removed them means that other implementation won't necessarily have them either. As long as only PyPy is known to have them, I'd use the PYPY guard instead of the CPYTHON guard here.

Thefunctions were removed from CPython in favour of `sys.get_asyncgen_hooks()`, which sounds rather annoying to call from C, but we could do that here.

> Is there a better way to work around the [opaque PyThreadState](https://docs.python.org/3/c-api/init.html?highlight=pythreadstate#c.PyThreadState) fields?

It's an opaque struct in the Limited API, not in regular CPython.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -167,7 +167,7 @@
   #undef CYTHON_USE_MODULE_STATE
   #define CYTHON_USE_MODULE_STATE 0
   #undef CYTHON_USE_TP_FINALIZE
-  #define CYTHON_USE_TP_FINALIZE 0
+  #define CYTHON_USE_TP_FINALIZE PY_VERSION_HEX >= 0x030400a1

comment_data.body: Just to be sure, this is not version specific in PyPy, right?

commit.message: unskip and fix some passing tests
get tests to run on a branch of PyPy
hack to avoid PyIter_Next and call tp_iternext instead
use a nightly build that has the function needed in 28fb74aefe
fix assert syntax in error_pos test
fixes from review, reskip failing test with explaination
limit CYTHON_USE_TP_FINALIZE to pypy 7.3.12 and above

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3str`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: unskip and fix some passing tests
